definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to be in a particular state or condition

examples.text: Hundreds of people were rendered homeless by the earthquake.

definitions.definition: to give somebody something, especially in return for something or because it is expected
definitions.sensetop: render something to somebody/somethingrender somebody somethingrender something

examples.text: They rendered assistance to the disaster victims.
to render a service to somebody

definitions.definition: to present something, especially when it is done officially

examples.text: The committee was asked to render a report on the housing situation.
He stood up and rendered a beautiful version of ‘Summertime’.
The artist has rendered the stormy sea in dark greens and browns.

definitions.definition: to express something in a different language

examples.text: The Italian phrase can be rendered as ‘I did my best’.
It's a concept that is difficult to render into English.

definitions.definition: to cover a wall with a layer of plaster or cement
to make fat liquid by heating it; to melt something

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French rendre, from an alteration of Latin reddere ‘give back’, from re- ‘back’ + dare ‘give’. The earliest senses were ‘recite’, ‘translate’, and ‘give back’ (hence ‘represent’ and ‘perform’); ‘hand over’ (hence ‘give help’ and ‘submit for consideration’); ‘cause to be’; and ‘melt down’.
